questions.text: Name the investigation shown-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PET-CT Explanation: It looks like a CT, it's a coronal image of a CT scan but on a CT scan you will not see a metabolic activity. That means this is a test which is hybrid of metabolic activity and anatomical activity. So it is PET-CT

questions.text: A 30 year old with motor vehicle accident presented to the causality with pelvic fracture. His vitals are stable but he is unable to pass urine. He has blood at the urethral meatus. An RGU was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Membranous urethra EXPLANATION : Everything is pointing towards urethral injury, RGU is shown. We can clearly see extravasation of the dye i.e. dye is coming out of the urethra which is right next to the pubic symphysis. The part of the urethra just below the bladder is the prostatic urethra, the part of the urethra at the level of pubic symphysis is the Membranous urethra, and part below it is bulbar and penile urethra, because the extravasation of the dye is happening at the level of pubic symphysis so it is pointing towards injury at Membranous urethra. INVESTIGATION: RGU

questions.text: A 11 month old child presented with recurrent abdominal On examination a mass can be felt in lumbar region. A barium enema study was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intussusception Explanation: This is a Barium enema in which you can see a claw sign.

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: The radio opaque shadow is visible, it is not stag horn calculus because it is mentioned it is delayed intravenous urogram. In IVU we can see contrast material, so there is dye in the pelvicalyceal system even after taking delayed scan the ureter is not getting opacified, so it suggest of Pelviuretric junction obstruction. Investigation: Delayed IVU

questions.text: A 22 year old female with primary infertility underwent HSG examination and shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Septate uterus Explanation: There is a Mullerian abnormality. We can see two cornua On HSG we look at the angle between the two cornua, if this angle is less than 60, we call it Septate. If it is wide apart we call it Bicornuate. So both the cornua are close to each other in the above question so we call it Septate uterus. Mullerian IOC : 3D USG

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ultrasound Doppler Explanation: Blood flow in doppler in form of waves, than it is DUPLEX SCAN.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with fever, expectoration and difficulty breathing. HRCT of chest was performed and shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Consolidation with air bronchogram Explanation: we can see the opacities in chest, the air filled bronchi are seen within the air cavity, if we see air filled bronchi within the opacities it is called AIR BRONCHOGRAM. And air bronchogram is classically associated with CONSOLIDATION.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Subarachnoid Haemorrhage Explanation: If there is a aneurysm in brain and if it ruptures it is Subarachnoid Haemorrhage. Subdural Haemorrhage is due to rupture of bridiging veins. Intracerebral Haemorrhage is due to hypertension seen in the Puttaman basal ganglia due to rupture of charcot bucket microaneurysm.

choices.text: Isolated osteoma of floor of mouth

questions.text: A 45 year old patient complaints of recurrent swelling in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the swelling. Imaging was performed and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sialolithiasis Explanation: This is the mandible, jaw is visible and we can see a radio opaque shadow in the sub mandibular area, this is a salivary gland stone. The patient have recurrent swelling, afraid of eating because it worsens the swelling and the x-ray is showing Sialolithiasis. IOC salivary gland stone : NCCT IOC for gall stone: USG IOC for urinary tract stone: NCCT IOC for urinary bladder stone: USG

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presented to the causality after a motor vehicle accident. He has bruises on the chest. His pulse is 100 bpm. BP is 125/85 and RR is 28. A chest Xray was performed and show below. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chest tube placement and drainage Explanation: Entire thorax appears very black, diaphragm is pushed down,the lung is herniated and pushed to the other side, mediastinum is pushed to other side, trachea is pushed to other side. It is very clear we are dealing with Tension Pneumothorax. Most appropriate step in the management will be Chest tube placement and drainage.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting? His vitals are stable. What is the most effective way to treat this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Explanation: There is gas below the diaphragm. This is Pneumoperitoneum We will perform Resuscitation and exploratory Laparotomy

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with fever dry cough, breathlessness and night sweats. On chest X-Ray, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy was seen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sarcoidosis Explanation: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy it is pointing towards systemic pathology and not infective pathology. Tuberculosis will be unilateral or asymmetric. On gallium scan on sarcoidosis – PANDA sign

questions.text: Prenatal USG in a 35 year old female showed a fetus with multiple fractures. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteogenesis imperfecta Explanation: if we see fetus with multiple fractures, we should consider the bones are weak and we call it Osteogenesis Imperfecta. Position of fractures in osteogenesis imperfecta is Diaphyseal and they are in different stages of healing. If in a child metaphyseal corner fracture or metaphyseal bucket handle fracture than we will go with Child Abuse/Battered baby.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Multiple enchondromas Explanation: Multiple lytic lesions in the phalanges, this is typical location for a benign tumor called Enchondroma. Syndrome of multiple Enchondroma is called as OLLIER disease. If multiple enchondroma also have hemangioma than MAFFUCI SYNDROME. If multiple Exostosis it is called as Diaphyseal aclasia Brown Tumor are associated with Hyper PT.

questions.text: An Industrial worker was admitted in the hospital with injury to the eye following his work with hammer & chisel, with suspected foreign body in eye. Which of the following investigations will be detrimental?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is contraindicated and potentially dangerous in cases of suspected metallic foreign body in the eye. This is because MRI uses strong magnetic fields, which can cause ferromagnetic objects (like metallic fragments) to move, heat up, or cause additional tissue damage within the sensitive ocular structures. In an industrial setting involving hammer and chisel, there is a high likelihood of a metallic foreign body. Performing an MRI before ruling out a metallic object can lead to serious complications including vision loss or even perforation of the globe. Other Options: A. CT Scan CT is the investigation of choice for detecting intraocular or intraorbital metallic foreign bodies, as it provides excellent detail of radio-opaque materials like metal. It is safe and highly sensitive in such cases. C. X-ray X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies but is less sensitive than CT. However, it is still a safe initial investigation, especially in resource-limited settings, to detect large or radio-opaque foreign bodies. D. B-Mode Ultrasonography (USG) While USG can detect intraocular foreign bodies, it should not be performed initially if globe integrity is compromised, as pressure from the probe can worsen the injury. It can be considered after excluding globe rupture with clinical examination or CT.

questions.text: Female patient comes with repeated miscarriage. What is the investigation being done.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hysterosalpingogram Explanation: Mullerian abnormality, we can only see 1 banana shape cavity of the uterus and a single fallopian tube arising from it. It is a Unicornuate uterus.

questions.text: 35 years old male, expansile swelling of distal forearm, near wrist joint. Xray Shown
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GCT Explanation: If we look at the x-ray we can see the lesion is expansile, eccentric, epiphysis, subarticular. It is GCT. (soap bubble appearance)

questions.text: Patient comes to you with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Putty Kidney Explanation: Sterile pyuria, on x-ray we can see calcification, one of the kidney is looking small and calcified that means there is chronic inflammation going on in the kidney. This is Tubercular Putty Kidney.

questions.text: Patient with Fatigue, 12 year old child. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Supracardiac TAPVC Explanation: Snowman heart, cottage loaf heart, fig 8 heart. Condition : Supracardiac TAPVC- Snowman

questions.text: Middle aged man with 2 year history of backache in morning and history of redness of eye.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ankylosing spondylitis Explanation: B/l sacroiliac joint have sclerosis and appear fused or ankylosed. Bamboo spine Diagnosis – Ankylosing spondylitis TB spine – IOC MRI (loss of disc space on x-ray) Osteopetrosis – bone within bone appearance, Rugger jersey spine

questions.text: Which part of the bowel is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Jejunum Explanation: IOC for intestinal obstruction – CECT Best x-ray – Abdominal supine Upto 3 air fluid levels are considered Physiological, if more than 3 than we call it as intestinal obstruction. Folds in the bowel these are called as Volvulae Conniventis than it is Jejunum. Ileum- featureless Colon- Haustra Duodenum- C shaped (1st part- cap shaped)

questions.text: Patient with abdominal distension and pain in Emergency Xray shown.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pneumoperitoneum Explanation: Inner and outer aspect of the bowel wall is visible,right upper quadrant is appearing more Lucent. These are all indirect signs of RIGLER’S SIGN, FOOT BALL sign. This is Pneumoperitoneum. Falciform ligament sign Inverted V sign due to outlining of umbilical ligaments Tell Tale triangle sign, Cupola sign

questions.text: Child with normal bone mineralization. Xray shown
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scurvy Explanation: whenever bone is formed it has 2 parts Osteoid formation and than there is Mineralization, now if you have Rickets it will effect the mineralization. If you have scurvy it will effect collagen formation and thus effecting Osteoid formation. In x-ray we can see White line of Frenkel, Wimberger Ring.

questions.text: Child playing left unattended by the mother. Develops difficulty swallowing. No distress. CXR shown. Where is the foreign body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Esophagus Explanation: If you see a complete circle it has to be in esophagus, in the trachea on the sagittal plane it will be seen end on.

questions.text: 12 year old with chronic ear discharge, fever. Ct scan is shown what is the complication shown?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Temporal lobe abscess Explanation: In the temporal lobe you can see a ring enhancing lesion with surrounding edema.

questions.text: Patient started on Radiotherapy for cancer, least affected by radiation exposure is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neurons in the brain are highly differentiated and non-dividing (post-mitotic) cells, making them least sensitive to radiation. Radiation primarily targets rapidly dividing cells because it damages DNA, which these cells need to replicate. Since neurons do not divide, they are relatively resistant to the effects of radiation, although high doses may still cause indirect damage via vascular or glial injury over time. Nonetheless, compared to other listed tissues, neurons are the least affected. Other Options: B. Spermatogonia These are rapidly dividing germ cells in the testes and among the most radiosensitive cells in the body. Even low doses of radiation can impair spermatogenesis. C. Erythroblastic Tissue in Bone Marrow Bone marrow contains rapidly proliferating hematopoietic cells, especially erythroblasts, which are very radiosensitive. Radiation can cause bone marrow suppression leading to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. D. Intestinal Mucosa The epithelial lining of the intestines turns over quickly, making it highly radiosensitive. Radiation can damage crypt cells, leading to mucositis, diarrhea, and malabsorption.

questions.text: Patient with untreated Spinal TB developed a swelling in the Left groin following which his left limb was in flexion and Internal Rotation. Which of the marked muscle responsible for the attitude of his limb?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Psoas Muscle Explanation: If you have TB in the spine, so the pus from the TB is tracking down the muscle and nerves into the distal area that is called Cold abscess, so there is a cold abscess in the groin because of which there is flexon and internal rotation of the limb. This is Psoas abscess in the Psoas muscle.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis of the particular X-ray?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A/c Laryngobronchitis Explanation: The airway is getting narrow – Steeple sign i.e. CROUP Epiglottitis – thumb sign

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of following CXR?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Teratotology of fallot Explanation: we can see there is oligimea in the lung field, the lungs are appearing dark the apex is right ventricular it is lifted up giving rise up to an appearance i.e. is BOOT shape/ Coven Sabot. TAPVC- Snowman Ebstein’s anomaly – Box shape heart VSD – Plethora, No cyanosis, Left atrium enlarged

questions.text: Pulmonomy plethora seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection) leads to pulmonary plethora due to increased pulmonary blood flow. In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not drain into the left atrium but instead connect anomalously to the systemic venous circulation. Blood returns from the lungs into the right atrium, causing volume overload and increased pulmonary blood flow. This results in vascular congestion and prominent pulmonary markings on chest X-ray, which is characteristic of pulmonary plethora. Other Options: B. Tricuspid Atresia Due to underdevelopment or absence of the tricuspid valve, there's reduced flow into the pulmonary circulation, leading to decreased pulmonary vascular markings, i.e., pulmonary oligemia, not plethora. C. Ebstein Anomaly In this condition, there's downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to right atrial enlargement and reduced forward flow to lungs. This results in pulmonary oligemia. D. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) TOF involves pulmonary stenosis and right-to-left shunt via VSD, which significantly reduces pulmonary blood flow. Chest X-ray shows boot-shaped heart with decreased vascular markings.

questions.text: A 20 years old man with hypertension has following CXR finding with aortic shadow as below. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Coarctation of Aorta Explanation: figure of 3 appearance on a chest x-ray is suggestive of Coarctation of Aorta. Inferior rib notching due to collaterals involving 3-8th rib also called as DOCK sign. Coarctation of aorta is also associated with TURNER SYNDROME.

questions.text: Remote after loading is used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Remote afterloading is a technique specifically used in brachytherapy, where a radioactive source is inserted into or near the tumor site after the applicator has been positioned in the patient. This is done remotely using a computerized system to enhance safety for medical staff by minimizing radiation exposure. The source is loaded only after the placement is verified, ensuring precise targeting and reducing complications. Other Options: B. Electron Beam Electron beams are delivered externally and do not involve the insertion of radioactive sources into the body. Hence, remote afterloading is not applicable. C. Proton Beam Proton therapy uses a beam of protons from an accelerator targeted at the tumor. It’s an external technique, and no radioactive material is implanted, so remote afterloading is not used. D. CyberKnife Therapy CyberKnife uses robotic arms to deliver focused external radiation with sub-millimeter precision. It does not use implanted radioactive sources, so remote afterloading is not relevant.

questions.text: Cystic lesion in suprasellar region with calcification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Craniophangioma Explanation: if suprasellar calcified tumor in a child it is always CRANIOPHANGIOMA. It is solid cystic tumor arises from the Rcthkc’s Pouch Remnent.

questions.text: 45 years old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity. There is no h/o trauma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) SAH Explanation: On the NCCT we can see blood in the basal cisterns, blood in the cerebral sulci On NCCT the blood clots will be hyper dense.

questions.text: Which sign is seen on USG when the femoral vein meets the GSV and femoral artery at sapheno- femoral junction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Mickey Mouse sign is a well-known ultrasound appearance at the saphenofemoral junction. It is named for its resemblance to the face of Mickey Mouse, where: The common femoral vein (CFV) forms the head, The great saphenous vein (GSV) and common femoral artery (CFA) form the ears. This sign helps in accurately identifying the anatomy during venous Doppler studies, especially for diagnosing venous insufficiency or planning varicose vein surgery. Other Options: B. String sign – Seen in GI imaging, especially in Crohn’s disease or hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, indicating a narrowed lumen. C. Tillaux sign – Related to Tillaux fracture, an avulsion fracture at the anterolateral tibial epiphysis in adolescents, not an ultrasound finding. D. Stoner's sign – Not a recognized medical sign in imaging or clinical literature.

questions.text: 35 yrs old man presenting with recurrent episodes of fever with chills and fatigue an MRCP image is given. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis Explanation: MRCP is non invasive, Heavy t2 wt, No endoscopy, No dye There are multiple narrowing/strictures in the bile ducts, there is a chronic inflammatory process, so it is Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: A O+ pt presents with with h/o thickening of skin and shortness of breath and B/L basal rales. Her CXR shows reticular opacities in B/L basal fields. What is the next step in the case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most appropriate next step in a patient with suspected interstitial lung disease (ILD), especially in the context of connective tissue disease (suggested by skin thickening), is to perform a High-Resolution CT (HRCT) scan of the chest. HRCT provides detailed imaging of the lung parenchyma and is superior to CECT or chest X-ray in detecting interstitial patterns such as ground-glass opacities, honeycombing, and reticulations, which are typical of ILDs like systemic sclerosis-associated ILD. It is considered the gold standard imaging for ILD evaluation. Other Options: A. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) – Not ideal as first step in ILD workup. CECT is more useful for masses, lymphadenopathy, or vascular lesions, but does not provide the fine parenchymal detail that HRCT does. Hence, not the best initial investigation in suspected ILD. C. Pulmonary Function Test (PFT) – Helpful but not first step. PFTs can confirm restrictive patterns and assess severity, but they are not diagnostic. They are typically done after HRCT has identified interstitial changes. D. Echocardiography – Useful for pulmonary hypertension screening, which may coexist, but is not the first diagnostic step when ILD is suspected. It’s more valuable later in the workup.

questions.text: Radiation dose monitoring in occupation of personal is done by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TLD Badge (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) is the standard device used for monitoring occupational radiation exposure in healthcare workers, radiologists, nuclear industry personnel, and others exposed to ionizing radiation. It contains a crystal (commonly lithium fluoride) that traps electrons when exposed to radiation. When heated, it emits light proportional to the radiation dose received. It is worn on the body (typically chest level) and replaced periodically to ensure that the cumulative exposure stays within the permissible safety limits set by regulatory authorities like AERB or ICRP. Other Options: B. Linear Accelerator – A machine used to deliver external beam radiation therapy; not used for monitoring radiation dose. C. Collimators – Devices that shape and direct the radiation beam, helping minimize exposure to surrounding tissues, but not used for personal dose monitoring. D. Grid – A radiographic device used to reduce scatter radiation and improve image quality in diagnostic radiology; again, not a monitoring tool for personnel exposure.

questions.text: Which is not a radiographic finding s/i CHF?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oligemia refers to reduced pulmonary blood flow, seen as decreased vascular markings on chest X-ray. This is typically observed in conditions with reduced pulmonary circulation, such as Tetralogy of Fallot or severe pulmonary stenosis, not in CHF. CHF causes increased pulmonary venous pressure, leading to vascular congestion—not oligemia. Thus, oligemia is not a radiographic finding of CHF. Other Options: A. Kerley B lines These are short, horizontal lines at the lung bases representing interlobular septal thickening due to pulmonary edema. Common in early CHF. B. Cardiomegaly An enlarged heart shadow (cardiothoracic ratio >0.5) is often seen due to left ventricular dysfunction or volume overload. D. Kerley A lines These are longer, oblique lines radiating from the hilum to the periphery due to engorged deep septal veins, indicating more severe or chronic pulmonary venous hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is water soluble contrast
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Iodine-based contrast agents are the primary water-soluble contrasts used in radiology. These are commonly used in intravenous, oral, and intra-arterial studies like CT scans, angiography, and urography. Their water solubility allows for rapid distribution and excretion, making them safe for internal use, especially when there's a risk of leakage or perforation (e.g., suspected GI perforation). Other Options: A. Barium – Not water-soluble. Barium sulfate is a suspension, not a solution, and is not absorbed by the body. It is contraindicated in perforation due to risk of barium peritonitis. C. Bromide – Not used as contrast. Although bromide ions can be radiopaque, they are not used as standard contrast media in clinical radiology. D. Calcium – Not a contrast agent. Calcium salts are not used as contrast media. They may show up on X-ray due to natural density but are not administered for imaging purposes.

questions.text: Identify the chest X ray of a patient with low grade fever
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Military TB Explanation: There are multiple small soft nodules in the lung which are 1-2 mm thick like millet seeds it is Miliary TB

questions.text: A patient presented with history of diplopia and restricted eye movements. A clinical image and a CT image is shown below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Blow out fracture Explanation: A blow out fracture is visible on the orbital floor and you can see the muscles going down into the sinus giving tear drop appearance.

questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Barium meal follow through Explanation: The image clearly shows barium meal follow through in the Small bowel.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the below image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lacunar infarct

questions.text: Following investigation is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Simple hysterosalpingography Explanation: There is a cannula in the cervix, uterus is visible and dye is spilling into the peritoneum this is normal routine Simple HSG. We do it for tubal patency.

questions.text: The following radiological image is showing which of the following disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Urethral stone

questions.text: The following image shows which of the following procedure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: The image displays a fluoroscopic (X-ray) image where a catheter or drain is clearly visible within the dilated biliary tree (the network of bile ducts within the liver) and extending down towards the duodenum. Contrast medium has been injected, outlining the biliary ducts. This procedure involves accessing the bile ducts from outside the body, typically through the skin (percutaneously) and liver (transhepatic), to relieve an obstruction and drain bile. This entire process is characteristic of a Percutaneous Biliary Drainage (D), often performed when the bile ducts are blocked (e.g., by a tumor or stone) and endoscopic drainage is not feasible. Now, let's analyze why the other options are incorrect: A. TIPSS (Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt): TIPSS is a procedure to create a shunt within the liver between the portal vein and a hepatic vein to relieve portal hypertension. While it's an interventional radiology procedure and involves the liver, the image shows the biliary system (bile ducts) being accessed and drained, not the portal venous system. B. Stenting for kidney stone: Stenting for a kidney stone typically involves placing a stent within the ureter (the tube connecting the kidney to the bladder) to bypass an obstruction caused by a stone or to help the stone pass. This procedure is performed in the urinary tract, not the biliary system, and the anatomy shown in the image (liver, bile ducts) is clearly not the kidney or ureter. C. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an endoscopic procedure where a scope is passed through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the duodenum. Contrast is then injected retrogradely (against the flow) into the bile and pancreatic ducts using a catheter inserted through the endoscope. While ERCP also visualizes the biliary tree and can involve stent placement or stone removal, it is an endoscopic procedure performed from the inside, not a percutaneous (through the skin) procedure with a visible external catheter entering the liver as seen in the image.

questions.text: A patient with suspected esophageal perforation. What is the safest contrast to be used for esophagography?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodine-based contrast agent. In cases of suspected esophageal perforation, water-soluble contrasts like Iohexol (or Gastrografin) are preferred because they are less irritating and safer if leaked into the mediastinum or pleural cavity. Using water-soluble contrast prevents severe chemical mediastinitis or peritonitis, which could occur if a non-absorbable agent like barium leaks through a perforation. Other Options: B. Barium sulphate – Contraindicated in perforation. If barium leaks into the mediastinum or peritoneum through a perforation, it can cause severe inflammation or fibrosis. Hence, not used in suspected perforation cases. C. Gadolinium – Used in MRI, not esophagography. Though it is a contrast agent, gadolinium is not used for fluoroscopy or esophagography, and not safe or practical for GI tract evaluation. D. Methylene blue – Used for leak testing, not radiologic imaging. It can be used during endoscopic or surgical procedures to detect leaks, but it is not a radiographic contrast agent for esophagography.

questions.text: In the following image of angiography, identify the artery shown:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Superior mesenteric artery Explanation: we can see artery arising from Aorta which has branches on both the sides, this indicates we are looking at Superior mesenteric artery. If we look at the Inferior mesenteric artery the branches are at the one side.

questions.text: A neonate presents with congestive heart failure, on examination enlarging fontanelle, bruit on auscultation, and radiological image (below) found. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vein of Galen malformation Explanation: If large head and heart failure together it indicates towards Vein of Galen Malformation. It is a congenital AV fistula in the median Prosencephelic vein. Because of AV fistula it predisposes to high output cardiac failure and develop obstruction to the CSF pathway and hydrocephalus.

questions.text: Bragg Peak
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Protons Explanation: Bragg peak is when a radiation beam is causing energy deposit at the target only with no surrounding damage, seen typically in Proton beam therapy. That is why Proton beam therapy is used in Skull Base Chondroma, Medulloblastoma, Uveal Melanoma.

questions.text: The following image shows sign of which disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Craniopharyngioma Explanation: This is a contrast enhanced MRI. Tumor is separate from the Pituitary, it is in the infundibulum it supra sellar i.e. Craniopharyngioma.

questions.text: A 40-years-old bedridden patient presented with sudden breathlessness. An investigation is shown below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pulmonary embolism Explanation: Bedridden patient with breathlessness is Pulmonary embolism. IOC – CT pulmonary angiogram Screening : D-DIMER Cx in Pulmonary embolism is usually NORMAL

questions.text: CT scan of thorax. Identify structure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pulmonary artery

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The x-ray image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cephalhematoma Cephalhematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone. It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 hours. The swelling is limited by suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Putty kidney Putty kidney is the characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis, specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-like calcification of the kidney appearing like a putty. It is caused by a dissemination of the organism through the blood stream and is thus always a secondary TB.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant.
Small intestinal mucosa is most radioresistant.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for various cancers. It works by targeting rapidly dividing cancer cells with ionizing radiation, which can damage the DNA of these cells and lead to cell death. Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature. Premature non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells Small intestinal epithelial cells which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of fever and cough for the past 3-5 days. His examination findings findings reveal crepitations. Chest xray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The chest xray shows opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation. The loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air.x

questions.text: A 31-year-old female delivered a 1 kg baby at 31 week of gestation. The child has hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. On CT Periventricular Calcification is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Congenital CMV (Cytomegalovirus) infection is the most common congenital viral infection and a leading cause of neurodevelopmental disability. Classic findings include: Periventricular calcifications (hallmark on CT) Hepatosplenomegaly Jaundice Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) Microcephaly Sensorineural hearing loss The presence of periventricular calcifications on CT is highly specific for congenital CMV, distinguishing it from other TORCH infections. Other Options: A. Toxoplasmosis – Usually shows diffuse intracranial calcifications, often basal ganglia and scattered throughout the brain, not typically periventricular. B. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) – Typically causes temporal lobe involvement and may lead to hemorrhagic necrosis, not commonly associated with periventricular calcification. D. Parvovirus B19 – Known for causing fetal hydrops and anemia, not CNS calcifications or hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A 32-year-old presented with altered sensorium. CT reveals Bitemporal hemorrhage. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herpes Simplex Explanation: A patient presenting with altered sensorium and bitemporal hemorrhage on CT scan, particularly if it involves the medial temporal lobes, is highly suggestive of Herpes Simplex Encephalitis (HSE). HSE is a severe and often life-threatening viral infection of the brain caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type 1 (HSV-1). It characteristically causes hemorrhagic necrosis, with a predilection for the temporal lobes (often unilaterally or asymmetrically, but bitemporal involvement is common), and the limbic system. The altered sensorium is a common symptom of encephalitis. Let's look at why the other options are less likely in this specific presentation: A. TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculous meningitis or tuberculoma can cause altered sensorium. However, bitemporal hemorrhage is not a typical radiological finding in CNS tuberculosis. TB lesions are usually granulomatous and might show enhancement, but not acute hemorrhage in this specific bitemporal pattern. C. Brain cancer: Brain tumors (primary or metastatic) can cause altered sensorium, and some aggressive tumors (e.g., glioblastoma, metastatic melanoma, renal cell carcinoma) can hemorrhage. However, bitemporal hemorrhage specifically affecting the temporal lobes in this manner is not the most common presentation for typical brain cancers and wouldn't be the primary diagnosis given the specific imaging finding without further context. D. Stroke: A stroke involves a sudden interruption of blood supply to the brain (ischemic stroke) or bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). While a hemorrhagic stroke would show hemorrhage on CT, a bitemporal, often non-aneurysmal, hemorrhagic pattern is not characteristic of a typical stroke, which usually follows vascular territories. While a stroke could theoretically involve the temporal lobe, the "bitemporal hemorrhage" specifically points away from a common stroke presentation and more towards an infectious or inflammatory cause like HSE.

choices.text: The normal cell and cancer cells will be equally sensitive
Gl mucosa is more resistant part
The radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source-coulomb law
Small blood vessels are resistant to the effect of radiation

questions.text: A 45-year-old female who has to undergo radiotherapy for treatment of Ca Cervix stage 2b. Which of the following statement is true regarding ionizing radiation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is correct in principle, though it incorrectly attributes the law to Coulomb (which relates to electrostatics). The correct law here is the Inverse Square Law, which states that radiation intensity decreases proportionally to the square of the distance from the source: Intensity ∝ 1 / Distance2 A. The normal cell and cancer cells will be equally sensitive Cancer cells are generally more radiosensitive due to their high mitotic rate, less efficient DNA repair, and less organized cell cycle regulation. Normal cells—especially those that are slowly dividing—tend to have better repair mechanisms, giving them relative resistance to radiation. B. GI mucosa is more resistant part The gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa is one of the most radiosensitive tissues in the body, especially the crypt cells of the small intestine, because of their rapid proliferation. This sensitivity explains why GI toxicity is a common side effect of pelvic radiotherapy. D. Small blood vessels are resistant to the effect of radiation Small blood vessels, particularly capillaries and arterioles, are sensitive to radiation. Ionizing radiation can damage endothelial cells, leading to fibrosis, ischemia, and late vascular complications such as tissue necrosis or telangiectasia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with history of trauma one week back presents with confusion and ataxia. He is on treatment for alcohol dependence and his last intake was 2 weeks back. CT scan reveals following finding. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) SDH (Subdural Hematoma) The crescent-shaped hyperdense collection seen on the CT scan, situated along the inner surface of the skull and compressing the underlying brain tissue (indicated by the red arrows), is the hallmark imaging finding of a subdural hematoma. This shape occurs because the blood accumulates between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, layers that loosely adhere to each other, allowing the hematoma to spread over a wider area following the contour of the brain. The patient's history of trauma one week prior is a significant predisposing factor for SDH, as it can cause tearing of the bridging veins that connect the cortical surface of the brain to the dural sinuses. The reported confusion and ataxia are neurological symptoms consistent with the mass effect and increased intracranial pressure resulting from the subdural hematoma. Furthermore, the patient's history of alcohol dependence, even with recent abstinence, can contribute to an increased risk of SDH due to potential coagulopathy and brain atrophy. Incorrect Options: A. Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage Intraparenchymal hemorrhage refers to bleeding directly within the brain tissue itself. On a CT scan, this typically appears as a localized, often rounded or irregular area of high density within the brain parenchyma, rather than a crescent-shaped collection along the skull's inner surface that displaces the brain. While trauma can sometimes lead to intraparenchymal hemorrhage, the imaging findings in this case are not characteristic of it. B. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. On a CT scan, SAH typically presents as high-density blood within the sulci (grooves) of the brain and in the basal cisterns at the base of the brain, often having a more diffuse or star-shaped appearance rather than a localized crescentic collection. While trauma is a potential cause of SAH, the CT image provided does not demonstrate the characteristic pattern of bleeding seen in this condition. C. EDH (Epidural Hematoma) An epidural hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the dura mater. On a CT scan, epidural hematomas typically have a biconvex (lens-shaped) appearance because the dura is tightly adhered to the inner surface of the skull at the sutures, limiting the spread of the hematoma. While a history of trauma can certainly lead to an epidural hematoma, the crescent shape of the blood collection seen in the provided CT image is not characteristic of an EDH. Furthermore, epidural hematomas are often associated with skull fractures, which are not explicitly mentioned in the clinical information or clearly visible in this single axial slice.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. His blood pressure in right arm is 100/60 and in left arm is 170/90. Chest Xray shows mediastinal widening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition caused by a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, leading to blood entering the aortic wall and separating its layers. The classic presentation includes: • Sudden, severe chest pain that radiates to the neck, back, or interscapular region • Asymmetric blood pressure between limbs (in this case, right arm 100/60 mmHg vs. left arm 170/90 mmHg), which is a hallmark sign due to involvement of different branches of the aorta • Mediastinal widening on chest X-ray, which strongly suggests aortic pathology These findings together are highly indicative of an aortic dissection, especially in an older hypertensive patient. Option A: Acute Pulmonary Embolism – Incorrect Pulmonary embolism can cause sudden chest pain and dyspnea, but it typically does not cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or mediastinal widening on chest X-ray. Instead, findings may include tachycardia, hypoxia, and possibly a normal chest X-ray or features like Westermark sign or Hampton’s hump. Option B: Acute Coronary Syndrome – Incorrect Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) also presents with chest pain, but it is usually central, crushing, and associated with risk factors like exertion. However, ACS does not typically cause radiating pain to the back or interscapular area, blood pressure asymmetry, or mediastinal widening. ECG and troponins are used for diagnosis. Option D: Esophageal rupture – Incorrect Esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome) can cause severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema, often following vomiting or trauma. It may also cause mediastinal widening, but the asymmetric blood pressure and interscapular radiation of pain are not typical, making this diagnosis less likely.
